subject: Re: [junit] Testing a TestCase - Making sure a failure is reported
msgSnippet: ... One possibility is: TestResult result = new TestResult(); case.run(result); assertEquals(0orWhatever, result.errorCount()); assertEquals(0orWhatever,
messageBody:
Francois Beausoleil wrote:
> // In my TestStaticSerialization TestCase
> public void testValidClass() {
> TestCase case = TestStaticSerialization(ValidClass.class);
>
> // Should never fail in any of these methods
> case.setUp();
> case.testEquals();
> case.testHashCode();
> case.testSerialization();
> }
>
> public void testInvalidClass() {
> TestCase case = TestStaticSerialization(InvalidClass.class);
> case.setUp(); // Should fail here !
> case.testEquals();
> case.testHashCode();
> case.testSerialization();
> }

One possibility is:
TestResult result = new TestResult();
case.run(result);
assertEquals(0orWhatever, result.errorCount());
assertEquals(0orWhatever, result.failureCount());
That's the way the tests coming with JUnit are asserted most of the
time. Using a TestListener would be more work but might be necessary if
you want to test the exact timing of failure/error occurrence.

Johannes
